Let $A\subseteq \mathbb{N}$ be a finite set of size $N$. Is it true that, for any fixed $t$, there are\[\ll \frac{2^N}{N^{3/2}}\]many $S\subseteq A$ such that $\sum_{n\in S}n=t$?

If we further ask that $\lvert S\rvert=l$ (for any fixed $l$) then is the number of solutions\[\ll \frac{2^N}{N^2},\]with the implied constant independent of $l$ and $t$?



Erd\H{o}s and Moser \cite{Er65} proved the first bound with an additional factor of $(\log n)^{3/2}$. This was removed by S\'{a}rk\"{o}zy and Szemer\'{e}di \cite{SaSz65}, thereby answering the first question in the affirmative. Stanley \cite{St80} has shown that this quantity is maximised when $A=\{-\lfloor \frac{N-1}{2}\rfloor,\ldots,\lfloor\frac{N}{2}\rfloor\}$.

The second question was answered in the affirmative by Hal\'{a}sz \cite{Ha77}, as a consequence of a more general multi-dimensional result.




References


[Er65] Erd\H{o}s, P., Extremal problems in number theory. Proc. Sympos. Pure Math., Vol. VIII (1965), 181-189.

[Ha77] Hal\'{a}sz, G., Estimates for the concentration function of combinatorial
number theory and probability. Period. Math. Hungar. (1977), 197--211.

[SaSz65] S\'{a}rk\"{o}zi, A. and Szemer\'{e}di, E., \"{U}ber ein Problem von Erd\H{o}s und Moser. Acta Arith. (1965), 205-208.

[St80] Stanley, Richard P., Weyl groups, the hard Lefschetz theorem, and the Sperner property. SIAM J. Algebraic Discrete Methods (1980), 168-184.
